latest news.eng_title: Mpox is again a global health emergency. How concerned should Californians be?
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization has declared the mpox virus, a variant of monkeypox, a global health emergency due to its high mortality rate and ease of transmission. The majority of cases have been reported in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where there have been 14,000 cases and 524 deaths this year. While the risk of mpox to the general public in the U.S. is considered very low, public health officials are concerned about the potential for the virus to spread further across countries in Africa and possibly outside the continent. Dr. Anne Rimoin, professor of epidemiology at UCLA, said, 'an infection anywhere is potentially an infection everywhere,' and emphasized the importance of early detection and response. Local officials in California are monitoring the situation and have issued advisories to healthcare providers to be on the lookout for Clade I mpox in patients with recent travel to Africa and symptoms consistent with mpox. The CDC recommends vaccination for certain groups of people, including those who have been exposed to mpox and gay, bisexual, or other men who have sex with men.
latest news.title: Mpox is again a global health emergency. How concerned should Californians be?

latest news.eng_title: Understanding the Difficulty of Evaluating the Danger of Mpox
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the mpox situation in the African continent a public health emergency of international concern due to the risk of global spread and a potential new pandemic. However, the level of danger posed by mpox is uncertain, and the mortality rate varies depending on the strain. In Africa, the disease has been present since 1970 and has a mortality rate estimated between 1% and 10%. In contrast, in Western countries, the mortality rate is much lower, around 0.2%. According to virologist Antoine Gessain, the risk to humans depends largely on the quality of healthcare in the region. In Africa, where the disease is more prevalent, the mortality rate is higher due to factors such as malnutrition and lack of access to proper medical care. The current outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with a mortality rate of 3.6%, would likely be lower if the virus were to spread to Western countries. The disease is also more contagious in areas with poor healthcare and among vulnerable populations, such as children and adults with compromised immune systems. The different strains of the virus, known as clades, also contribute to the complexity of the situation. The current outbreak in the DRC is caused by the clade 1, while the 2022-2023 outbreak was caused by the clade 2. The situation has led to confusion in the media, with some outlets describing the new subvariant 1b as more deadly than previous ones, without sufficient evidence to support this claim. According to virologist Marion Koopmans, 'we read in the main media things that are quite categorical about the gravity or danger of the new subvariant 1b, without much to back them up.'
latest news.title: Mpox: entenda a dificuldade de avaliar o perigo da doença

latest news.eng_title: The Difficulty of Evaluating the Danger of Mpox
latest news.summary: The difficulty in assessing the danger of mpox has increased since 2022, when the disease spread worldwide. In new countries, especially in the Western ones, the mortality rate has been very low, around 0.2%. According to virologist Antoine Gessain, 'The danger to humans largely depends on (...) the quality of healthcare in the region where they live.' It is more likely that a patient will receive immediate and appropriate treatment in Europe or the United States than in most African countries. Therefore, it is probable that the current mortality rate of 3.6% in the DRC, the epicenter of the ongoing epidemic, would be much lower if the virus were to start circulating actively in Western countries.
latest news.title: A dificuldade de avaliar o perigo da mpox

latest news.eng_title: WHO Declares Global Health Emergency Over Mpox Outbreak
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a global health emergency due to the outbreak of the mpox virus, also known as monkeypox. The new strain of the virus appears to cause more severe illness and spread more easily, particularly among children under 15 years old in Africa. The WHO has clarified that mpox is not the new COVID-19, and that the risk is not the same. The organization has recommended vaccination only for vulnerable populations, such as immunocompromised individuals. The Jynneos vaccine, approved by the FDA in 2019, requires two doses administered four weeks apart and is considered safe for people with weakened immune systems, HIV, and dermatitis atópica. The mpox virus can be spread through close contact, including kissing and sex, as well as through contact with infected skin lesions and bodily fluids, or by touching contaminated objects. According to the CDC, over 17,500 cases and 500 deaths have been reported in at least 13 African countries as of early 2024.

latest news.eng_title: Africa: Mpox Outbreaks in Africa Constitute a Public Health Emergency of Continental Security

Organization: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
Title: Director General

latest news.summary: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) declared mpox a public health emergency of continental security (PHECS) in Africa on August 13, 2024, due to the worsening situation on the continent. Since 2022, 40,874 cases and 1,512 deaths have been reported across 15 African Union (AU) member states, with a 160% increase in cases and 19% increase in deaths in 2024 compared to the same period in 2023. The Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) accounts for 96% of all cases and 97% of all deaths reported in 2024. The outbreak is driven by heterosexual transmission, especially among female sex workers, and raises concerns about vertical transmission risks and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The high risk of severe infection among people living with HIV, limited access to medical countermeasures, and low detection rates are also concerns. The Africa CDC Director General was advised by the 15-member Emergency Consultative Group (ECG) to declare a PHECS, which was redefined as a significant event posing a risk to other countries, requiring immediate continental-level action to prevent and mitigate disease spread. The ECG developed specific criteria to assess the situation objectively, including disease severity, transmission dynamics, and public health risk.
latest news.title: Africa: Mpox Outbreaks in Africa Constitute a Public Health Emergency of Continental Security

latest news.eng_title: Mpox risk low but imported cases may increase in Europe: EU agency

Organization: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

latest news.summary: The European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has reported that the risk of mpox virus remains low in Europe, but there could be an increase in imported cases. ECDC expert Orlando Cenciarelli stated that individuals who have had contact with mpox patients are at a higher risk, but the disease generally presents as mild. However, those with underlying health conditions and weakened immune systems may experience moderate to severe illness if infected. Cenciarelli recommended that vaccines should be offered only to those at risk of infection, individuals with severe illness, and those traveling to regions where transmission is likely. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Europe, Europe recorded 27,000 cases and 10 deaths due to mpox in the summer of 2022. The WHO and the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have declared mpox a public health emergency of international and continental concern. Africa CDC's latest data shows 17,541 mpox cases and 517 deaths across 13 African countries, with the Democratic Republic of the Congo being the epicenter of the outbreak, responsible for 96% of all cases and 97% of all deaths reported in 2024.

latest news.eng_title: WHO Assures that Mpox Epidemic is Not a Cause for Panic
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has assured that the mpox epidemic is not a cause for panic. According to the WHO, the recent increase in cases is not comparable to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to global lockdowns. The WHO has declared mpox as a public health emergency of international concern, but emphasizes that the situation is under control. The organization recommends that countries maintain vigilance and work together to combat the virus. Additionally, the WHO suggests that governments purchase vaccines. In Brazil, the Ministry of Health has established an Emergency Operations Center to coordinate responses to mpox. The country is currently at the lowest level of global emergency for the disease, with 709 confirmed or suspected cases reported in 2024. The last reported death from mpox was in 2023. 'The situation is under control,' said the WHO, 'we are not seeing a pandemic like we saw with COVID-19.'

latest news.eng_title: Cross border movement, poor response capacity drivers of Mpox spread
latest news.summary: The Africa CDC has declared Mpox a public health emergency of continental security (PHECS) in Africa due to the high risk of spread between neighboring countries and globally. The agency highlights cross-border movement, low public understanding of Mpox transmission, and insufficient response capacity as major challenges. The agency also notes that the vaccine shortage is a serious threat to containment efforts, and many African countries are highly vulnerable to Mpox infection due to widespread malnutrition and the prevalence of HIV. 'The high case fatality rate of over 3.9 per cent, particularly among children younger than 15 years, who account for 60 per cent of cases, further complicates the outbreak,' the agency said. The agency reported that heterosexual sexual activities, particularly among sex workers in Congo, are a major driver of Mpox transmission. Africa CDC Director General Dr Jean Kaseya appealed to the international community to provide support, saying 'Don't punish Africa. We need solidarity, we need you to provide appropriate support, this vaccine is expensive.' The agency is currently in talks with Bavarian Nordic to transfer technology to enable African manufacturers to produce the vaccine locally, with a goal of having 10 million doses available by the end of 2025.

latest news.eng_title: Can the COVID-19 Pandemic Teach Us Anything About Containing Mpox? A Global Health Expert Weighs In.
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared mpox a global public health emergency of international concern due to the rapid spread of the virus in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and neighboring countries. Rebecca Katz, a professor in the School of Medicine and School of Foreign Service, explains that mpox is an infectious disease that can cause painful rash, blisters, aches, and fever, as well as swollen lymph nodes. The virus has caused occasional outbreaks in parts of Central, East, and West Africa for decades, and epidemiologists have tracked thousands of cases a year in mostly Central Africa for the last 20 years. Katz notes that while the risk of mpox spreading widely in the U.S. is low, people need to exercise caution and vigilance. She emphasizes the importance of taking early action, devoting resources for surveillance and response, and ensuring access to healthcare, medical countermeasures, and support for infection, prevention, and control. The WHO is coordinating a global response to mpox, raising resources to support the response, and ensuring that populations that need drugs and vaccines are able to access them.
latest news.title: Can the COVID-19 Pandemic Teach Us Anything About Containing Mpox? A Global Health Expert Weighs In.

latest news.eng_title: WHO says Mpox outbreak is not the new COVID. Here's what you should know about it
latest news.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the mpox outbreak a global health emergency, but emphasized that it is not the new COVID. According to the WHO, more than 17,000 cases have been reported in Africa in 2024, and over 32,000 cases were reported in the US from 2022 to 2023. Mpox can spread through direct contact with infected animals, people, or contaminated materials, and anyone who has close contact with someone with symptoms or multiple sex partners is at risk. WHO regional director Hans Kluge said, 'The risk of mpox is not limited to people who are sexually active or gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men.' Federal officials have stated that the risk of a widespread outbreak in the US is low, with only a few cases of clade II mpox reported each week. From 2022 to 2023, 58 people died from mpox in the US.
latest news.title: WHO says Mpox outbreak is not the new COVID. Here's what you should know about it

news knowledge.eng_title: Mpox: ECDC Warns of Increased Risk of Imported Cases in Europe
news knowledge.summary: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has warned that it is 'highly likely' that new cases of the more virulent mpox variant, clade 1b, will be reported in Europe in the coming weeks. The ECDC has assessed the risk of sustained transmission among Europeans as 'very low', but expects more imported cases from African countries, where a surge of the new variant is underway. The ECDC recommends that imported cases be quickly diagnosed and treated to prevent local transmission of the new strain. Due to the high volume of travel between European and African countries, the ECDC recommends that EU countries publish travel guidance for people in areas affected by the mpox outbreak in Africa. The probability of infection in these cases was evaluated by the ECDC as 'high'. According to ECDC Director Pamela Rendi-Wagner, 'As a result of the rapid spread of this outbreak in Africa, the ECDC has increased the risk level for the general population in the EU and for travelers to affected areas.' 'Due to the close links between Europe and Africa, we must be prepared for more imported cases of the new variant,' she added. The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the new outbreak a 'public health emergency of international concern' on August 14. Since the new variant was first recorded in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), cases have been confirmed in Burundi, Kenya, and Rwanda, as well as in Sweden. According to CDC data, there have been 38,465 reported cases of mpox and 1,456 deaths on the African continent since January 2022, but the numbers include different viral strains. The virus is transmissible through close contact and sexual relations. Symptoms of mpox, formerly known as monkeypox, typically appear 6-13 days after infection and include fever, headache, muscle pain, and skin lesions. Most people experience mild to moderate symptoms, but individuals with compromised immune systems may develop more severe cases.
news knowledge.title: Mpox: doença deve se espalhar pela Europa nas próximas semanas, diz agência

news knowledge.eng_title: Mpox News Today: Mpox surveillance and management measures being put in place, says Health Ministry
news knowledge.summary: The Union Health Ministry in India has stated that there are no reported cases of Mpox in the country, but measures are being put in place for surveillance and management out of caution. The Ministry said that the risk of a large outbreak with sustained transmission is presently low for India, but the situation is being monitored. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), Mpox infections are usually self-limiting and patients generally recover with supportive management. The transmission requires prolonged close contact with an infected case and is generally through the sexual route or direct contact with body/lesion fluid or contaminated clothing/linen of an infected person. The WHO has reported 99,176 cases and 208 deaths due to Mpox globally since 2022, and India has reported 30 cases since the 2022 declaration, with the last case being in March 2024. 'Although the possibility of a few imported cases being detected in the coming weeks is not entirely ruled out, it was assessed that the risk of a large outbreak with sustained transmission is presently low for India,' the Ministry said. 'This is the second time the WHO is declaring Mpox a public health emergency, the last time being July 2022. It was revoked in May 2023,' the Ministry added.
news knowledge.title: Mpox News Today: Mpox surveillance and management measures being put in place, says Health Ministry

news knowledge.eng_title: Europe's CDC releases mpox risk assessment after Swedish case detected

Organization: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control

keywords: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
news knowledge.summary: The European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has released a risk assessment and updated guidance for mpox in Europe after a case of MPXV clade Ib was reported in Sweden. The ECDC stated that the likelihood of infection in the general population in the EU/EEA is very low, provided that imported cases are diagnosed promptly and control measures are implemented. However, the likelihood of infection for close contacts of possible or confirmed imported cases is assessed high. The ECDC also warned that the risk is high for EU/EEA citizens traveling to or living in nations most affected by mpox in Africa, especially if they have close contact with affected communities. The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared mpox a global public health emergency and is committed to coordinating the global response to prevent transmission, treat those infected, and save lives.
news knowledge.title: Europe's CDC releases mpox risk assessment after Swedish case detected

news knowledge.eng_title: Lauterbach sees no significant Mpox threat for population
news knowledge.summary: German Health Minister Karl Lauterbach does not see a significant Mpox threat to the population, despite the first case of the new variant in Europe. 'Mpox pose no great danger to our population at the moment,' he said. The case in Sweden does not change the risk assessment for Germany and Europe, as it is a virus variant that is currently only endemic in parts of Central Africa. Lauterbach stated that Germany successfully contained the first outbreak of the previous Mpox variant in 2022 and is continuing to monitor the situation. The EU's health agency ECDC has warned EU member states to prepare for an increase in cases, as the rapid spread of the virus in Africa has increased the risk for the population within the EU. The ECDC estimates the risk for the general population in Europe as low, but moderate for people who have close contact with possible or confirmed Mpox cases. For travelers to Africa who have close contact with infected individuals, the risk is high.

According to ECDC director Pamela Rendi-Wagner, 'There will be more cases in the coming weeks. That's the expectation... But regarding the risk [for the] general European population, we have to say that our assessment is that the risk is very low at the moment.' The statement comes as the WHO declared mpox a global public health emergency due to the ongoing outbreak in parts of Africa. Data from the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) show that over 2,000 new mpox cases have been reported across Africa in the past week alone, with a total of 38,465 cases and 1,456 deaths reported since January 2022.

news knowledge.eng_title: ECDC Labels mpox Risk in EU as 'Low'

Organization: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control

news knowledge.summary: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has assessed the risk of mpox in the EU as 'low' after a new evaluation published on Friday, following the international health emergency declared by the WHO on Wednesday. According to the report, 'the probability of infection with clade I of the human immunodeficiency virus (MPXV) for EU/EEE citizens traveling or living in affected areas and having close contact with affected communities is high.' However, they assure that the probability of infection is 'low as long as contact with affected communities is avoided.' 'In general, the risk for these populations is moderate and low, respectively,' they indicate. The ECDC also notes that the general risk for the general population of the EU/EEE is assessed as low, based on a very low probability and a low impact. However, they warn that the severity of the disease is moderate among people 'with underlying diseases, particularly immunocompromised individuals,' whose risk with respect to the disease is high. The ECDC also considers it 'very likely' that there will be more imported cases of mpox (formerly known as monkeypox) in the continent, but ruled out the possibility of sustained transmission if appropriate measures are taken. 'The probability of sustained transmission in Europe is very low, as long as imported cases are diagnosed quickly and control measures are implemented,' they stated. The ECDC recommended that EU and EEE countries issue guidelines for those visiting or returning from areas affected by the mpox outbreak. 'As a result of the rapid transmission of this outbreak in Africa, the ECDC has increased the risk level for the general population in the EU and EEE and for those traveling to affected areas. Due to the close ties between Europe and Africa, we must be prepared for more cases of clade I imports,' said the director of the ECDC, Pamela Rendi-Wagner. The ECDC advises health authorities to maintain 'high levels of preparedness plans and awareness-raising activities to enable rapid detection and response to any clade I case that may arrive in Europe.' 'To detect cases of clade I mpox in the continent and activate any response, it will be vital to ensure effective surveillance and (perform) laboratory tests, epidemiological research, and contact tracing capacity,' stated the ECDC.

news knowledge.eng_title: Mpox in Lower Saxony: Low Risk Assessed by State Health Office
news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has raised its highest alert level due to a new variant of the Mpox virus in Africa, but the Lower Saxony State Health Office (NLGA) assesses the risk for Lower Saxony as low. Since the increase in Mpox cases in Lower Saxony in May 2022, the number of cases has decreased significantly due to intensive public health efforts: there were 58 reported cases in 2022, 2 in 2023, and only one so far this year (as of August 14). The cases are related to the 2B clade, as reported by the authority. The new virus variant of the I clade, which is associated with the outbreak in Africa, has not been detected in Germany so far. The Robert Koch Institute (RKI) currently assesses the risk to public health in Germany as low, and the NLGA agrees with this assessment. NLGA President Fabian Feil stated, 'The NLGA does not currently assess the risk for Lower Saxony as increased.' In cooperation with the health authorities and the RKI, the situation will be closely monitored. While a limited outbreak is still possible, a significant increase in cases like in 2022 is not expected, according to the RKI. As a precaution, unvaccinated individuals with high infection risks, such as adult men who engage in same-sex relationships and frequently change partners, as well as laboratory staff working with infectious laboratory samples, are advised to get vaccinated. Early detection of infections is crucial to prevent transmission. Healthcare professionals should include Mpox in the diagnosis for individuals with unclear pock-like skin changes, especially if they have recently returned from Central Africa. The virus is related to the classical smallpox virus and causes skin rash, fever, and can be fatal, especially for children. The smallpox vaccine also provides protection against Mpox infection.

news knowledge.eng_title: WHO Declares Mpox a Global Public Health Emergency

Organization: African Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Title: Director-General

news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the mpox (formerly known as monkeypox) situation in Africa as a global public health emergency of international concern due to the risk of global dissemination and a potential new pandemic. This is the highest level of alert from the organization. According to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, outbreaks of mpox have been reported in the Democratic Republic of Congo for over a decade and infections have increased over the years. In 2024, cases have already surpassed the total registered in 2023, with over 14,000 cases and 524 deaths. 'The WHO has been working to contain the mpox outbreaks in Africa and alerting that the situation is something that should concern us all. Last week, I convened the emergency committee to assess the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo and other countries in Africa. Today, the committee met and informed that, in their view, the situation constitutes a global public health emergency of international concern,' said Tedros. He reminded that the African Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC Africa) had already declared the mpox situation in the region as a public health emergency of continental security. The announcement was made yesterday (13) by the Director-General of the entity, Jean Kaseya, citing the rapid transmission of the disease in Africa. 'I accepted the committee's recommendation. The detection and rapid dissemination of a new mpox variant in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the detection of the same variant in neighboring countries that had not previously reported cases of the disease and the potential for dissemination across Africa and beyond are very concerning,' said Tedros. 'It is clear that a coordinated international response is essential to interrupt these outbreaks and save lives. A global public health emergency of international concern is the highest level of alarm in public health legislation,' concluded.
news knowledge.title: Organização Mundial da Saúde declara mpox como emergência em saúde pública global

news knowledge.eng_title: WHO Declares Public Health Emergency Over New Mpox Variant

Organization: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
Event: Public Health Emergency of International Concern
Title: Director-General

news knowledge.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a 'Public Health Emergency of International Concern' (PHEIC) due to a new variant of the Mpox virus in Africa. The WHO has activated its highest alert level, citing the risk of the Mpox virus spreading internationally again after 2022 and posing a health risk to several countries. According to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the decision was made after independent Mpox experts, who met in an emergency committee, recommended it. The WHO is not taking any concrete actions, but rather wants to alert authorities worldwide to prepare for possible outbreaks. A new virus variant, named Ib, was discovered in the Democratic Republic of Congo in late 2023. It may be more contagious and cause more severe illness than previous variants. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) has assessed the risk of the new variant spreading in Europe as 'very low' by the end of July. There are currently no known cases of the Klade I in Germany, according to the Robert Koch Institute (RKI). The Mpox virus is related to the classical smallpox virus and can cause skin rash, fever, and in severe cases, death, especially in children. The vaccine against smallpox also protects against Mpox. The African CDC has reported over 14,000 suspected cases and over 500 deaths in the Democratic Republic of Congo and neighboring countries this year. The WHO expects less than 1,000 laboratory-confirmed cases worldwide per month, but notes that many cases may go undetected due to lack of testing capacity. The WHO had previously declared a PHEIC for Mpox in July 2022, but lifted it in May 2023 after outbreaks were brought under control with vaccines in most countries. However, in Africa and other low-income countries, vaccine supply remains a challenge.

news knowledge.source_id: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

news knowledge.summary: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has assessed the risk of the clade I mpox outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to the United States. The overall risk to the general population is assessed as VERY LOW, with moderate confidence. The risk to gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (MSM) who have more than one sexual partner and people who have sex with MSM, regardless of gender, is assessed as LOW to MODERATE. The CDC has moderate confidence in this assessment, citing uncertainties around epidemiologic and genomic data in DRC. The assessment relies on subject-matter experts evaluating a range of evidence related to risk, including limited epidemiologic data from the DRC outbreak, historical data on clade I mpox epidemiology and clinical severity, and extrapolations based on the ongoing clade IIb mpox outbreak in the United States. The CDC will review available evidence every two weeks, or if the situation changes significantly, and update this assessment as warranted.
news knowledge.title: Mpox Rapid Risk Assessment
